question: During which lunar phase can a lunar eclipse occur?

content.source_1: A lunar eclipse occurs when the Moon moves into Earth’s shadow (its umbra or penumbra).
content.source_2: Earth’s shadow is cast directly away from the Sun; the umbral cone extends on the night-side line opposite the Sun.
content.source_3: At full moon, the Moon is opposite the Sun in the sky as seen from Earth (about 180 degrees of elongation).
content.source_4: Any eclipse requires syzygy: the Sun, Earth, and Moon must be aligned nearly in a straight line.
content.source_5: A new moon occurs when the Moon lies between Earth and the Sun, a configuration that places the three bodies in line.
content.source_6: The Moon’s orbit is tilted about 5 degrees to Earth’s orbital plane, so eclipses (of either type) occur only when the Moon is near one of its orbital nodes.
